I am almost two thirds of the way through Kushiel's Justice.  With this book, Jacqueline Carey has transcended the power of the original trilogy about Phedre.

If I ever move a reader as profoundly as she does at a couple places thus far in the story, I will be content.
My God, I had such mixed emotions, putting him on the bus to go this morning...

When I posted the meme where I offered people an opportunity to ask me question on various topics,
thenewwavechick
asked me a question about religion, that started me thinking about some things. She specifically asked me how I feel about Paganism, which started me thinking about religion - which has already been a major topic in my mind lately, with the ongoing polarization of America into the religious-conservatives (aka the Red States) and the big-city liberals (aka the Blue States).

One of the core freedoms we established in our constitution was that our government would make no provision (I know, I am paraphrasing) putting any religion or sect ahead of any others. Diversity of faith - the freedom to worship as we choose - was a key tenet of belief for the Founding Fathers. Personally, I embrace such a worldview - and am horrified by the dogmatism of many faiths.

C.S. Lewis, in the final Narnia book, made a powerful point about dogmatism (through Aslan). Aslan is faced with a Calormene who was virtuous in the service of the demonic Tash, and some of his followers question why the Calormene is in Aslan's realm - which is basically Heaven. Aslan replies that he recognizes the virtue of the man regardless of whether his service was done in Aslan's name, or in Tash's. Aslan rewards good, and not evil, no matter which name is invoked for divine notice. Thus it is possible for someone who follows another faith to reach paradise.

While I am not God, to be able to say who gains access to Heaven or not - I draw a humanistic parallel. I do not care if a person is Christian, or Jew, or Muslim, or Buddhist, or Hindu, or any sect within these, or any other faith. What I care about is the quality of the person. To me, most faiths have the ability to inspire us to do good. Does it really matter whether the person doing good believes he cannot eat any non-kosher food? What is the difference between obeying the Golden Rule to "Do unto others as you would have them do unto you", or the exhortation to "Do as you will, if it harms no one"? Does it matter whether you call the idea that what comes around, goes around karma, or reaping what you sow?

To me, when any person states that they have an exclusive grasp on truth, that is a warning sign. Religions, by definition, are based articles of faith - belief in things that inherently cannot be proven to a certainty. Due to this, there is no way to prove that any specific faith is true, or that it has an exclusive lease on the truth.

In that way, religion is like the Terminator's programming. If any of you remember the blackly humorous scene in the first Terminator film, when Arnold is performing field surgery in his motel room after slaughtering a precinct of policemen. The door of his room is pounded on by a man who wants to know what the heck is creating the hideous smell coming from Arnie's room. In this sequence, we see a menu of replies appear in the head's up view of the Terminator, and it choose one that seems to fit the circumstances - "Fuck you, asshole." The situation did not require violence to protect the machine's anonymity, so a verbal response was chosen.

For us non-cyborgs, Religion - our faith - goes a huge way towards shaping our morals and ethics. Those morals and ethics provide us with the options we choose from in response to life's ongoing stimuli.

Ironically enough, most faiths provide similar templates for morality - which causes me to ask what the big deal is about how a person chooses to worship. Does their faith matter so much as long as that faith contributes to them being good?

And I am horrified because I see us charging towards a theocratic state - that is the end result of the path we are starting down. And I think our Founding Fathers would be just as horrified.

Whether the theocracy is headed by Nehemiah Scudder or George W. Bush is irrelevant - the fact that we are headed where Heinlein predicted (for details, read Revolt in 2100, which collects the stories about the fall of the United States theocracy) is terrifying enough.

How many of you have been watching the new FX show, Damages?  If you are not watching it, I highly recommend it, especially if you were a fan of The Practice before it morphed into Boston Legal.

This legal drama hits all the right notes, while running a story told from two perspectives: Shortly after a young, ambitious associate lawyer's ex-fiance is killed and she is taken into police custody; And, in flashback, the events that lead to her being in the situation she is in, as she comes on-board with a law firm headed by Glenn Close (playing the scariest woman I have ever seen her play, even more frightening than her character in Fatal Attraction).

The action is very much in the FX shades-of-gray style - no one is totally pure, even the idealistic lead.

It is worth a watching - and watch it closely - because (like other dramas nowadays) missing details shown during an episode can be critical...

I'm going to go ahead and create the Harry Potter continuity community that I previously mentioned. 

The community name is
hp_expuniverse
.

Any of you who are interested - feel free to join!

Some rentals from Netflix lately:

The Life of David Gale:  This movie, through flashbacks, tells the tale of a anti-death-penalty activist who ends up on death row after the murder of one of his colleagues.  Like the gothic tales of the 19th and early 20th Century, the film draws you in irresistibly, until, one way or another, you are ensnared.  An effective film - but for my money - I think Dead Man Walking was a better film about being on death row...

The Covenant:  I went into this film with diminshed expectations - after all, it is another one of those teen suspense/horror films, and we all know how good they are, as a general rule...  wrong.  While I had some minor quibbles with the way they handled the magical duels between characters in this film - I think it works out to be one of the best films Renny Harlin has made.  Like some other films I can think of, it benefitted from using a cast of relatively-unknown stars.

1. Leave me a comment saying anything random, like your favorite lyric to your current favorite song... or your favorite kind of sandwich. Maybe your favorite game. Or just something random. Whatever you like.
2. I respond by asking you five personal questions so I can get to know you better.
3. Update your LJ with the answers to the questions.
4. Include this explanation and offer to ask someone else in the post.
5. When others comment asking to be asked, you will ask them five questions.

And here is the first set of answers - for
thenewwavechick
!

1. What is your favorite TV show?
Currently - I would have to say Top Chef.  (This changes frequently)

2. Do you like horror movies, and if yes, which one is your favorite?
Yes, to horror (but not slasher).  My favorite horror film of all time?  Jaws.

3. What do you think of the Geiko Cavemen having their own sitcom?
It is a shame when that is the idea for a scripted sitcom that made it through to get bought by a broadcast network.

4. If you won a contest to have a celebrity chef come and cook dinner for your family, who would you like to cook for you?
My celebrity chef is something of an almost-celebrity.  Her name is Lee Ann Wone - and she was one of the top four from Top Chef, season 1.

5. Who would you like to protray you in a movie of your life?
Some unknown actor with soulful brown eyes and the ability to deliver flawless deadpan humor.

1. List seven habits/quirks/facts about yourself.
2. Tag seven people to do the same.
3. Do not tag the person who tagged you or say that you tag whoever wants to do it.

The things about me:

1.  I miss the days when I used to have a once- or twice-weekly tabletop RPG game group to play with.
2.  I still prefer to have my mouse on the left-hand side (and have reversed buttons) of the keyboard - this dates back to the days when I used to do a lot of ten-key data entry.
3.  I am sorry to say that I will never achieve half of the things I wish I could.  I am afraid that the list of achieved dreams will be even less...
4.  I have worn glasses for more than 32 years.
5.  I once stuck a key into an electric socket.  I am very fortunate that I did not get killed by the experience.
6.  Right now - almost all of my games and movies and about half of my music CDs are in hock - having a week off without pay hurt us badly.
7.  I am not ashamed of the fact that I enjoy "kids books" like the Harry Potter books, The Chronicles of Narnia, and Lloyd Alexander's writing.

From back when Michael Jackson was one of the coolest performers on the planet.

I was terribly shocked by the collapse of the I-35 W bridge last night.  It was bridge I am familiar with, having crossed it a few times during various visits to the Twin Cities (specifically during the wife's pregnancy with Joshua).  It was quite a shock.

Of course, thank goodness for children - during the coverage, my eldest (Nathan - 4 1/2) asked what was wrong with the bridge, and how did it get "broke"?  The way he asked it was just so cute, and it helped us handle the news.

I am glad to see that those on my friends-list from the area are okay.

All things considered - it sounds like only a few lives were lost (amazingly).

I will have a severely diminished net=presence over the next few weeks, as I have an enforced week off from work due to the account I am on going out of business today, and then starting training for a new account on the 9th of July.  I will check in as I can, but please forgive me for not being as frequent a poster...

It was late at night on the open road, speeding like a man on the run
A lifetime spent preparing for the journey.
He is closer now and the search is on, reading from a map in the mind:
Yes there's that ragged hill and there's a boat on the river.

And when the rain came down, he heard a wild dog howl
There were voices in the night
(don't do it!)
Voices out of sight
(dont't do it!)
Too many men have failed before, whatever you do;

Don't pay the ferryman!
Don't even fix a price!
Don't pay the ferryman
Until he gets you to the other side.

In the rolling mist, then he gets on board, now there'll be no turning back
Beware that hooded old man at the rudder.
And then the lightning flashed and the thunder roared,
And people calling out his name,
And dancing bones that jabbered-and-a-moaned on the water.

And then the ferryman said "there is trouble ahead,
So you must pay me now."
(don't do it!)
"you must pay me now."
(don't do it!)
And still that voice came from beyond, whatever you do;

Don't pay the ferryman!
Don't even fix a price!
Don't pay the ferryman
Until he gets you to the other side.

How can I express what I think about
psychosymphony
?

Simply put - this man has been through about as much as I have - and he is someone who understands where I come from on many levels.  As a fellow traveler and comrade, he is someone whose words mean a great deal.  No matter what, I know that I am not alone, that he has seen some of the same horrors and travails I have.

And that makes him a friend to be treasured.

I was wondering:

1.  Chris Benoit and his wife, Nancy, first got together when they had an affair, sparked during a storyline in the WCW.

2.  There were numerous occasions where Chris Benoit showed very public demonstrations of his love for his son, Daniel, including at Wrestlemania XX.

3.  Just a year before Wrestlemania XX, Nancy Benoit filed for divorce from Chris Benoit, asking for full custody of their son.

4.  This suit was later retracted.

One wonders if Benoit felt he was going to lose his son, and was driven to the point where (in a manner similar to Shakespeare's Othello) he made the choice that if he couldn't have his son, no one else would either...  It would then make (twisted) sense why he killed his wife, as she was the one threatening to take his son away from him.

If this line of supposition is correct, then Chris Benoit is a very tragic figure - and one wonders who it was that played his Iago...

southernoracle
,
southernoracle
, wherefore art thou
southernoracle
?

She is a dynamic and highly intelligent woman who is setting out on the beginning of an exciting odyssey across America as she relocates into my old stomping grounds.  She is someone I wish I was able to share the time on the road with, because it would be a great adventure and a heck of a lot of fun.

She is a voracious reader who is whipping my pants on the 52-book challenge for this year - although she has more free time than I do.

And she is certainly someone whose words, both in comments and in her journal, during the time I have come to read them - have been welcomed and enjoyed.  Her support and friendship is a treasure I am grateful for.

What can I say about
salacioussusan
?

She is an extremely loyal friend and a very sexy woman.  She is a sensualist whose lusty outlook towards life can be very infectious, and her staunch support of her friends is a ray of sunlight in the land of Internet dishonesty and deceit.  She is also a creative woman and a talented performer, and one I would love to see on stage someday.

And did I say she is delectable?

She is.

Chris Benoit, according to the news reports on television and the Internet, strangled his wife, smothered his seven-year-old son, and then hung himself over the weekend.  This is a man who most fans of professional wrestling, especially those who knew the wrestlers outside of the ring, would point to as a true role model of being a good man and a consummate professional.

I just cannot believe that this has happened.  Initial reports are citing possible 'roid rage as what caused Benoit to go on this rampage.

Someone please tell me that this is all an instance of a mass bad dream, one we'll wake up from soon...
